Comment:
This is a very turbulent game played between myself (White, 1615) and harmo (1727).
It is played in the extremely aggressive Muzio Gambit line of the King's Gambit, in which white sacrifices a Knight to develop quickly and attack the black king with dynamic and active (though outnumbered) pieces.
But is that enough?
The King's Gambit accepted.
The King's Gambit accepted.
The King's Gambit accepted.
I opt for the Knight's Gambit and he responds with g5, the classical defense.
I opt for the Knight's Gambit and he responds with g5, the classical defense.

I play bc4, which is a valid alternative to h4.
He plays g4, threatening a subsequent queen check on h4 when the Knight moves...

I play bc4, which is a valid alternative to h4.
He plays g4, threatening a subsequent queen check on h4 when the Knight moves...
The Muzio Gambit.
He accepts and then plays queen f6,which, according to theory,is the best move in this position.
He accepts and then plays queen f6,which, according to theory,is the best move in this position.
He accepts and then plays queen f6,which, according to theory,is the best move in this position.
I play e5 to deflect the queen from f7, and he takes.
I play e5 to deflect the queen from f7, and he takes.
I play a very risky line involving a Bishop sacrifice on f7 that draws out the black king.
I play a very risky line involving a Bishop sacrifice on f7 that draws out the black king.
I play d4 to open more files, and he accepts this last sacrifice as well.
I play d4 to open more files, and he accepts this last sacrifice as well.
I develop quickly with be3 and fight for compensation.
He goes back...
I take on f4, threatening a discovered check on e5.
I take on f4, threatening a discovered check on e5.
I pile up on f6.
So he defends.
I develop and threaten to play Knight d5.
He prevents that.
So, I exchange on f6 and then plan nd5.
He covers f6.
He covers f6.
He covers f6.

I bring the last piece into the game and threaten the very venemous check on e7.
Now, the hunt for the black king can begin.
He decides to allow an exchange and later fork on f7 in order to protect his king, which proves invaluable later on.
